abstract.text: Apply textures to the surface of your scene’s 3D objects to give each object a unique appearance.

inlineContent.text: Materials define the appearance of 3D models in RealityKit, by defining how their surfaces interact with light. Materials can also occlude objects behind them, hold shaders, or act as portals to view other worlds with
RealityKit includes a few material types to help you get started, including
for basic color and textures, and
for realistic lighting effects such as reflections, roughness, and emission.

abstract.text: A component that turns mesh surfaces into portals to a different world.
An alias for the face culling object that’s appropriate for this
material class.
Describes the texture managed by the drawable queue
The type used to represent base color.
Synchronize the contents of entities locally or across the network.
A type that describes the material aspects of a mesh, like color and
texture.
A texture object that you use to create custom materials.
An object that defines the transparency options for a custom material.
An object that defines the roughness of an entity’s surface.
The custom material’s optional shader function that can manipulate an
entity’s vertex data.
A material that doesn’t respond to lights in the scene.
Simulate and render 3D content for use in your augmented reality apps.
A container for resources that will be encoded into a CustomMaterial’s custom uniforms argument buffer.

An object used to specify the intended usage of a texture.

abstract.text: Use low-level mesh and texture APIs to achieve fast updates to a person’s brush
strokes by integrating RealityKit with ARKit and SwiftUI.

coating scatters light to create soft highlights.
